items.cdc_internal_description: Current food industry trends, such as the reliance on imported foods and centralized food processing, are affecting the health of the public and placing a burden on understaffed inspectors who investigate foodborne disease outbreaks. Learn how foodborne illness and death can be reduced in the US and abroad.

This first session of Public Health Grand Rounds, ?Getting to Zero Traffic-related Deaths,? takes a look at motor vehicle safety. Hear about the role key risk factors, such as not wearing seat belts, alcohol, and speeding, play in traffic deaths, and learn what CDC is doing to prevent these deaths.

Hear about the legislative successes in tobacco control efforts, including the FDA’s ability to regulate the content, marketing and sales of tobacco products. Learn about the challenges that lie ahead in saving millions of lives through the reduction of tobacco use.

This session of Grand Rounds looks at eliminating Healthcare-associated Infections (HAIs). Pennsylvania was the first state to report HAI data hospital-wide. Learn what healthcare settings can do to eliminate HAIs, and the role that Medicare and Medicaid play in eliminating HAIs.

ALS is a rapidly progressive, fatal neurological disease. Researchers don?t know what causes ALS and there is no cure. The National ALS Registry was created in 2010 to help scientists learn who gets ALS and what causes it. Learn about research, drug development, and patient care options and the role of the ALS Registry.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a group of developmental disabilities that can cause significant social, communication and behavioral challenges. CDC data shows an estimated 1 in 68 children are affected by ASD. Learn about the challenges and opportunities of understanding, diagnosing, and screening this complex disorder.

Changes occurring in the world?s climate pose significant threats to human health and wellbeing and will have even greater impacts in the future. Find out how CDC is using its prevention expertise to help states and cities investigate, prepare for, and respond to the health effects of climate change.

The expanded role of pharmacists will position them to have greater impact in health care and public health. Beyond the dispensing of medications, pharmacists also provide a spectrum of prevention and treatment services to help improve health outcomes. Learn about the importance of including pharmacists in team-based care.

Have you ever wondered what kind of impact CDC science has? CDC?s Science Impact Framework measures science impact towards health outcomes, through five levels of influence: disseminating science, creating awareness, catalyzing action, effecting change, and shaping the future. Learn more about the Framework here.
